user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of irq:
```c
static int irq(void)
{
	int rc = 0;
	char *err_msg="";
	enum metal_log_level mll= metal_get_log_level();
	int i, tst_irq[2];

	/* Do not show LOG_ERROR or LOG_DEBUG for expected fail case */
	metal_set_log_level(METAL_LOG_CRITICAL);

	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		/* we only want to test the lib API, so create 'virtual' IRQs */
		tst_irq[i] = eventfd(0,0);
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s: irq %d associated with fd %d\n",
			  __func__, i, tst_irq[i]);
	}

	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[1], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 1 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}

	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 after unregistering failed\n";
		goto out;
	}
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[1]);

out:
	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		close(tst_irq[i]);
	}
	metal_set_log_level(mll);
	if ((err_msg[0] != '\0') && (!rc))
		rc = -EINVAL;
	if (rc) metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s", err_msg);
	return rc;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (rc) metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s", err_msg);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The variable err_msg is declared as char *err_msg = "" and later assigned string literals (e.g. "register irq 0 fail drv_id 1\n"). String literals should be pointed to by pointers to const char. In the fragment if (rc) metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s", err_msg); err_msg is a non-const pointer to a const object, so Rule 8.13 is violated. Fix by declaring err_msg as const char *err_msg = "" (and propagate const where needed).
